questionListItems.title: What are the regulatory requirements that a large charity needs to adhere to with regards to the change of auditors?

answer.body:
Large charities are required to engage an external auditor who has been approved by the Sector Administrator to audit its financial statements. It is stipulated in Regulation 5 of the Charities (Large Charities) Regulations that large charities shall change its auditor at least once every five years, whether to another auditor from the same auditing firm or company or to another auditor from a different auditing firm or company. Please note that the five year limit should start from the first year the charity was extended to a large charity.

 

Please log in to the Charity Portal (http://www.charities.gov.sg), click on “Update Charity Profile” and download the “Auditor Declaration Form” under  the e-service “Appointment of Auditor (for IPCs or Large Charities)”. Thereafter, please complete the application and submit the said declaration form via the Charity Portal. The COC or Sector Administrator will review the application and applicant will be notified when the application is approved.

topics.title: Registering as a Charity in Singapore

questionListItems.title: Are exempt charities with financial size exceeding $10 million regulated under the Charities (Large Charities) Regulations?

answer.body: No. According to Regulation 3(1) of the Charities (Large Charities) Regulations, the provisions stipulated in this regulation will not apply to (a) any large charity with IPC status; and (b) any exempt charity.

topics.title: Registering as a Charity in Singapore

questionListItems.title: What is an International Charity Organisation (ICO)? Are the procedures and criteria to set up an ICO different from that of a charity?

answer.body:
The International Charity Organisation (ICO) Scheme has been retired with effect from 13 March 2018. All applications for charity registration by International Non-Profit Organisations (INPOs) will be administered in accordance with the requirements provided under Regulation 3 of the Charities (Registration of Charities) Regulations.

INPOs which were registered before the retirement of the ICO Scheme are considered registered charities and should continue to meet the requirements under the Charities Act and regulations, as well as the economic criterion set by the Economic Development Board (EDB) during its charity registration. There are no changes to the reporting and annual submission requirements for such charities under the retired ICO Scheme.

 

(As the ICO scheme has been phased out, applicant are advised to comply with the requirements stipulated under the Charities (Registration of Charities) Regulations if it intends to register as a charity in Singapore.)

topics.title: Registering as a Charity in Singapore

questionListItems.title: Can an overseas registered charity set up a foreign branch in Singapore? Will it be required to be registered as a charity?

answer.body:
As long as the objects of the organisation are exclusively charitable and it meets the basic registration requirements, the organisation is required to apply for charity status in Singapore. In the event that it does not fulfil basic registration requirements or its application is rejected, it may still operate in Singapore as a society/company but will not enjoy the tax exemption benefit that is applicable to registered charities.

 

Please also note that any organisation who wishes to raise funds for foreign charitable purposes must apply for a permit from the Commissioner of Charities. Please visit the Charity Portal >> “Fund-Raising” >> “Fund-raising Permits or Licenses” for more information.

topics.title: Registering as a Charity in Singapore

questionListItems.title: How can member(s) of public verify if an organisation is a registered charity?

answer.body: Member(s) of the public may verify if an organisation is a registered charity by performing a basic Search on the Charity Portal. Simply enter the name of organisation, click on “Search”, and the results will be generated. For further information of the charity such as contact details, click on the hyperlink on the name of the charity.

topics.title: Registering as a Charity in Singapore

answer.body: A foundation is perceived as an organisation with its own sources of funding (e.g. financed by a donation or a legacy provided by an individual or company or unsolicited private donations) dedicated to educational, religious, research or other charitable purposes. Due to the connotation that it is self-funded, foundations should not conduct any public fund-raising appeal to raise funds for its activities.

questionListItems.title: Can the word “Foundation” be used in the name of an organisation to be registered as a charity?

answer.body: The word “Foundation” can only be used if the organisation is (a) self-funded by an individual, family or for-profit company to aid your organisation’s intended charitable purposes, or (b) financed by an endowment. The “Foundation” should not be conducting any public fund-raising appeal to raise fund for its activities.

Grantmakers are typically non-profit entities such as private (family, corporate, etc) foundations, community foundations, and businesses’ giving programmes, which only give out grant monies to specific charitable causes. Grantmaking itself is not a charitable purpose, but grantmaking for the advancement of any of the charitable purposes described below could be considered charitable:

 

  • Relief of poverty;

  • Advancement of education;

  • Advancement of religion;

  • Other purposes beneficial to the community, such as promotion of health; advancement of citizenship or community development; advancement of arts, heritage or science; advancement of environment protection or improvement; relief of those in need by reason of youth, age, ill-health, disability, financial hardship or other disadvantages; advancement of animal welfare; and advancement of sport, where the sport promotes health through physical skill and exertion.

questionListItems.title: Can Grantmakers register as a charity?

answer.body: Yes. Grantmakers can register as a charity either under the “Regular Scheme” or the “Grantmaker Scheme”.

questionListItems.title: What are the requirements to register a Grantmaker as a charity under the regular scheme?

answer.body:
To qualify for charity registration, the organisation has to comply with the following requirements under the Charities Act/regulations:

a)     The governing instruments provide for the purposes or objects of the organisation and the purposes or objects must be exclusively charitable;

b)     The organisation must have at least three governing board members, of whom at least two must be Singapore citizens or permanent residents; and

Purposes or objects of the organisation must be beneficial wholly or substantially to the community in Singapore.

questionListItems.title: What is the lighter touch regime for Grantmakers?

answer.body:
In line with Government’s effort to promote Singapore as a philanthropic hub, the lighter touch regime for Grantmakers was designed to facilitate charity registration for these organisations. Under the lighter touch regime, some of the basic charity registration criteria such as having a minimum of three governing board members can be waived or relaxed, subject to review on a case-by-case basis.

 

For details, please refer to the “Guidance on Regulations of Grantmakers”  which can be downloaded from the Charity Portal >> Guides, Templates and Awards.

questionListItems.title: Who qualifies for the Grantmaker scheme under the lighter-touch regime?

answer.body:
Grantmakers who meet the following criteria may qualify for the lighter-touch regime:

 

  • The grantmaker must be a non-profit and a non-governmental organisation;

  • The grantmaker has its source of funds, from an individual, family or institution (whether corporate or not);

  • The grantmaker must be established to aid exclusively charitable purposes through the provision of grants;

  • The grantmaker must not be a registered Institution of a Public Character (IPC).

questionListItems.title: What are the regulatory requirements that will be relaxed or waived for qualifying grantmakers under the lighter-touch regime?

answer.body:
The COC’s Office will waive the requirements for qualifying grantmakers (where applicable) and accept a minimum of one (1) local board member (which could be a corporate entity such as a bank or a law firm).

 

Qualifying grantmakers will not need to apply their funds wholly or substantially in Singapore. However, as charities enjoy income tax exemption, there is an expectation that they should still conduct activities that benefit the community in Singapore. Hence, qualifying grantmakers registered as charities should still apply some of their funds in Singapore.

 

Grantmakers will be exempted from submitting the Online Financial Summary (OFS) and the Governance Evaluation Checklist (GEC). However, they are still required to submit their Annual Reports and Financial Statements via the Charity Portal.

questionListItems.title: Are qualifying grantmakers under the lighter-touch regime allowed to conduct fund-raising appeals?

answer.body: A grantmaker registered under the lighter-touch regime will need to be solely funded by an individual, family or institution (whether corporate or not). As it has to be funded with private monies, no form of private or public fund-raising appeal is permissible. Notwithstanding this, a grantmaker may accept donations from other private sources so long as no appeal for funds were made to these parties.

questionListItems.title: Are qualifying grantmakers under the lighter-touch regime allowed to solicit for donations/grants and charge fees for their services/programmes/activities?

answer.body: Grantmakers under the lighter-touch regime are not allowed to solicit for donations and grants or charge fees for their services/programmes or activities.
